cards.title: Wimbledon 2015 / How are you experiencing it?

item.title: Wimbledon 2015: how are you experiencing it?
item.trailText: Whether camping and queueing for tickets, or watching the action overseas, share your Wimbledon experiences with us
item.standFirst: Whether camping and queueing for tickets, or watching the action overseas, share your Wimbledon experiences with us
item.body:
Since Wimbledon is one of very few major sporting events where tickets are still available on the day of play, we’d like to hear from anyone who is camping in Wimbledon Park during the tournament, and joining the daily queues in the hope of securing those all important Centre Court tickets.

If you do not plan on pitching up your tent at Wimbledon, we’d like to know how you are planning on enjoying the tournament. Has your garden been transformed into a centre court for you to watch every game, set and match with strawberries and cream? Or will you be holed up in a dark room for two weeks with the air conditioning on? You might be a huge Wimbledon fan currently living overseas, having to burn the midnight oil to get a chance to see your favourite players in action. Wherever you are in the world, we’d like to see your Wimbledon photos and experiences. We’ll feature the best of them on our site.

You can share your Wimbledon pictures, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ button on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments’ – and if you add it to the homepage – you can keep up with all our assignments.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Meera Syal webchat / Post your questions now

item.title: Meera Syal webchat – post your questions now
item.trailText: The actor and author of new novel The House of Hidden Mothers is joining us for a live webchat on Tuesday 30 June at 1pm BST – post your questions in the comments below
item.standFirst: The actor and author of new novel The House of Hidden Mothers is joining us for a live webchat on Tuesday 30 June at 1pm BST – post your questions in the comments below

blocks.title: Post your questions for Meera Syal
blocks.body:
Actor, novelist, screenwriter, musician – Meera Syal is one of those multihyphenate talents who has tried a bit of everything and is, almost annoyingly, capable of it all.

She’s perhaps best known for her characters on Goodness Gracious Me and The Kumars at Number 42, two shows that put British-Asian life at the heart of the national conversation; her screenplay for Bhaji on the Beach did a similar thing back in 1993. Syal’s recent performance in David Hare’s Behind the Beautiful Forevers was much praised, as were her appearances in British TV perennials Holby City and Doctor Who. She even had a stint in all-Indian girl band Saffron.

During all this she has written three novels: the semi-autobiographical Anita and Me, Life Isn’t All Ha Ha Hee Hee, and now The House of Hidden Mothers, about a 47-year-old woman trying to start a family with her young lover. Syal is joining us to discuss it and anything else in her hugely varied career, in a live webchat from 1pm BST onwards on Tuesday 30 June. Post your questions in the comments below, and she’ll answer as many as possible.

cards.title: Welfare / Share your experiences of receiving child and working tax credits
cards.rawTitle: Share your experiences of receiving child and working tax credits

item.title: Are you receiving child and working tax credits? Share your experiences
item.trailText: Child and working tax credits look increasingly likely to be targeted by the government when cutting the welfare bill. How will this affect your finances?
item.standFirst: Child and working tax credits look increasingly likely to be targeted by the government when cutting the welfare bill. How will this affect your finances?
item.body:
Ahead of the budget on July 8, child tax credits and working tax credits look likely to be targeted by the government as part of its mission to cut the welfare bill. We’d like to hear from anyone currently receiving either what the likely effect any cuts would have on their finances.

We are particularly interested in hearing from anyone in the constituency of Blackburn with Darwen, though we do want to hear from you if you live elsewhere in the UK. Share your experiences and we’ll hopefully use your most interesting responses in our reporting

Please use the form below to submit your response - it won’t be visible on the site. You don’t need to supply your real name, but please do leave contact details if you’re happy for us to get in touch. You can also email us at guardian.witness@theguardian.com

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: London exodus / Have you moved out?

item.title: Have you moved out of London? Share your experiences
item.trailText: With house prices and rents spiralling many have made the decision to leave the capital. We’d like to hear from people who’ve made the move. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.standFirst: With house prices and rents spiralling many have made the decision to leave the capital. We’d like to hear from people who’ve made the move. Share your experiences via GuardianWitness
item.body:
“When a man is tired of London, he is tired of life,” said Samuel Johnson. Now many of the city’s residents disagree, fleeing London to get a life. The reasons are often financial, but can also be a desire for a change of pace or new experiences. It could even be the policies of another Johnson.

We’d like to hear from people who’ve left the capital – whether that’s to another city, the countryside or even abroad. And also from those who are welcoming them (or not).

What’s it really like when you leave? Has the move been everything you’ve hoped for – or have there been unexpected downsides? We’d like to hear about your experiences – both the good and the bad. What do you miss most about London living and what are the benefits of where you live now?

Share your stories – and photos and do let us know where you’ve moved to and your reasons for leaving London. We’ll publish the most interesting responses on the Guardian site.

You can share your photos, videos and stories by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons on this article. You can also use the GuardianWitness smartphone app or the Guardian app and search for ‘GuardianWitness assignments.’

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.

cards.title: Tips, links and suggestions / What are you reading this week?
cards.rawTitle: What are you reading this week?

item.title: Tips, links and suggestions: what are you reading this week?
item.trailText: Your space to discuss the books you are reading and what you think of them
item.standFirst:
Your space to discuss the books you are reading and what you think of them

  • Scroll down for our favourite literary links
  • Read more Tips, links and suggestions blogs
item.body:
Welcome to this week’s blog. Here’s a roundup of your comments and photos from last week, including discussions on re-reading and amazing books that mysteriously ended up in a reader’s bookshelf – plus our favourite literary links.

AggieH shared a discovery:

I do not know who Ryan Boudinot is. I read a fair few books. I read a fair amount about books. I just read Ryan Boudinot’s The Littlest Hitler. I do not know how I do not know who Ryan Boudinot is. I do not understand why this writer and this book has not been reviewed, recommended and hyped to a point that made me cry: “Oh for pity’s sake, not another article about bloody Boudinot! Isn’t Gaiman ever going to get a look in?”

(Searching for it just now on The Guardian yielded one result, a story about a three-year-old boy called Adolf Hitler Campbell whose birthday cake a bakery refused to decorate.)

Why is this book on my shelf? Where did I come across it? Who told me about it? Was it one of you? Who should I hug? Whoever it was, you should really be hugging me, whispering “there, there”. After reading these 13 stories, I’m simultaneously terrified, befuddled, bemused, amused, excited, dazzled and dazed.

The stories are every genre and none. Weird, dystopian, utopian, fantastical, realistic, surrealistic, absurd, satirical, romantic. The writing’s so pitch-perfect it’s invisible, but I can’t substantiate with quotes. Partly because I was too immersed to take notes. Mostly because the power lies in the cumulative effect. (I was reminded of Can Xue.) [Read the rest of the comment]

A warm welcome to the community for MildGloster, who hit the ground running with this first comment:

I’m currently reading Into the Silence: The Great War, Mallory and the Conquest of Everest by Wade Davis and have been doing so since last week. It’s a hugely researched and detailed account of the early Everest expeditions — and not just a revision of the expeditions themselves but a biographical study of the people involved, a political study of British colonialism in Asia, a geographical study of the Himalayas, and – essentially, and perhaps most interesting to me – a putting of the Everest expeditions into their historical context: why these men did it, and what it meant to them (and, in fact, to the world). Many of the men involved seem to have made Everest their mission in life, and viewed the conquest of it as having a meaning far deeper than that of simple personal gratification; a belief that following the abject misery of the First World War, their achievement would mean something for Great Britain itself, that it would be an inspiration to the British people – “a climbing expedition that would become the ultimate gesture of imperial redemption”.

This belief could be viewed, charitably, as admirable, even noble in its way – but it is just the sort of attitude that tends to possess an awfully ugly side, too. As Davis writes, the British mountaineering community in the early twentieth-century was anything but a meritocracy – I believe almost every one of the men involved in the expeditions was public school-educated, if not Oxbridge-educated – and I’ve found Davis’s insights into that rather fascinating; why particular climbers were chosen for the expeditions, and others were not. One incident recounted sums it up: Sydney Spencer, editor of the Alpine Journal, is in conversation with a friend and glances out of a window at a street sweeper, “casually” commenting that, “his Alpine Club would never admit such an individual, even if he were the best climber in the world”.

conedison posed a great question:

Stoner’s one of the greatest novels I’ve ever read. However, I can’t see myself ever reading it again – I’m just not that much of a masochist.

Question: have you ever read a book you believe to be truly great and at the same time know you’ll never read it again?

Some of the answers:

I don’t imagine I will want to put myself once again through the gut-punch that was Revolutionary Road, although I loved it unconditionally and have been devouring Yates’ books ever since. We’ll see. Perhaps it’s not a book one wants to revisit for fear of finding too many parallels with their own life come middle-age. –WebberExpat

I’m not convinced that one can ever say never to rereading, but if I think of a book I can’t quite imagine myself picking up again it would perhaps be something like Anna Karenina [by Leo Tolstoi] — because it’s utterly beautiful, but it’s also utterly exhausting. For that reason, and that reason alone, I can’t envision myself taking the time to go through all of it again; however, I may feel different when I’m older – perhaps it will want me to read it again when I’m 35, or 49, or 61. I don’t know. –MildGloster

I thought Alone in Berlin [by Hans Fallada] was an extraordinary book, but years later I am still haunted by it and know I could never read it again. I see people reading it on the tube and have to stop myself from going over and saying “whatever you do, don’t read the last 40 pages on public transport”. –RunningBecky

And Sara Richards reflected on why she likes re-reading books:

I don’t really have a high pain threshold, just an abysmal memory. Thinking about a book as a work of art, and putting literature into the same realms as art, music, poetry and so on makes the case for rereading. I could never know all there is to know about any art form from one visit. I also revisit at different times of my life bringing new experiences to bear. Some music I have listened to all my life and still find something new every time, something to make me catch my breath and relearn the work emotionally. It’s the same with reading. Each decade brings its own wisdom, or otherwise, and great works of literature demand a renewed acquaintance.

Vladislav Slyusarev shared this picture of his “readings and ridings of June”:

NZBarry added to the recent talk about travel writing:

I am a big fan, and have some vague notion that I’d like to do some academic study of the genre. I am currently reading John Gimlette – he seems to delight in following in someone else’s footsteps and then providing a doubled travel narrative. I first came across him a few years ago when I read Theatre of Fish, which follows his great-grandfather’s trail around (primarily) Newfoundland and Labrador. His great-grandfather kept a journal, which is quoted liberally, but as an adjunct to Gimlette’s account of modern Atlantic Canada and its post-fish economy.

I am presently about 2/3 of the way through Panther Soup, which takes him from Marseille to Switzerland, following the trail of a US Army company which made the same journey (under rather different circumstances) right at the end of the war. I’m finding it a fair bit more lively than Theatre of Fish, mainly (I think) because his source (an army Lieutenant) is with him, and retracing his own steps as a civilian.

Interesting links about books and reading

  • A Book Buyer’s Lament: “Unread books remind me of promises made to read them when they were bought; some of these promises are now decades old.” A New Yorker piece that we know will resonate with many of you...
  • A Roomful of Death and Destruction: Swelter recommended this read for “those who, like me, have enjoyed Luc Sante’s looks at historical New York City crime and vice in Low Life and Evidence.” The New York Review of Books article talks about a collection of police evidence photos spanning over fifty years of the 20th century.

[...] besides preserving the physical facts of important events and highlighting trends and aberrations in social behavior over the decades, the pictures record innumerable details of the appearance and atmosphere of the city in those decades. From them you can learn what kitchens looked like, how grocery stores decorated their display windows, how much trash accumulated in the street, what hazards attended the operation of open-top flivvers, and all about the wild variety of social clubs, illicit and otherwise, fancy or outré or irredeemably basic, that occupied an awful lot of the real estate in any era. They provide a vital and even visceral link to the city’s past, at a time when three-dimensional remnants of that past—buildings, along with their occupants—are being eliminated every day.

  • Dark Side of the Spoon: The Moods and Recipes of Nigel Slater: on the beauty and charm of great food writing – particularly of Nigel Slater’s, of which we have a weekly taste here on the Guardian.
  • What Is Asian American Literature, Anyway? In which Celeste Ng, author of Everything I Never Told You, dismantles Asian-American stereotypes and representation in literature and the possibility of “tricking” her readers.
  • Ten Writers Nobody Reads: a piece on Literary Hub “in praise of those we’ve lost to the literary wilderness”.

If you would like to share a photo of the book you are reading, or film your own book review, please do. Click the blue button on this page to share your video or image. I’ll include some of your posts in next week’s blog.

And, as always, if you have any suggestions for topics you’d like to see us covering beyond TLS, do let us know.

bodyImages.caption: The Sixth Extinction by Elizabeth Kolbert: ”To argue that the current extinction event could be averted if people just cared more and were willing to make more sacrifices is not wrong, exactly; still, it misses the point. It doesn’t much matter whether people care or don’t care. What matters is that people change the world.” Photograph: Shrey Goyal/GuardianWitness

It doesn’t much matter whether people care or don’t care. What matters is that people change the world.”

cards.title: Weekend / 40 things our readers were doing other than Glastonbury
cards.rawTitle: 40 things our readers were doing other than Glastonbury

item.title: 40 things our readers were doing this weekend other than Glastonbury
item.trailText: From attending London Pride to being the goalie in a Beat the Goalie contest, loads of you got up to things that weren’t Glastonbury related
item.standFirst: From attending London Pride to being the goalie in a Beat the Goalie contest, loads of you got up to things that weren’t Glastonbury related
item.body:
We decided to leaven our Glastonbury coverage with a bit of non-Glastonbury coverage. Accordingly, on Friday we asked us to tell us what you were up to over the weekend, excluding those in the vicinity of Worthy Farm.

We had a lovely response. According to our readers, Britain at the weekend is a land of hobbyists and dog lovers, of country walkers, village fete volunteers, karate competition competitors and Pride parade attendees. And, of course, workers.

Here is a selection of our favourite responses. The full gamut is ready for your perusal on GuardianWitness.

For the record, I played Pro Evolution Soccer, had a curry, went to Bristol to visit friends, and cycled along the Kent coast trying to find an abandoned Hoverport.

What you were getting up to this weekend

1) Attending London Pride

2) Riding a horse into the sea in Anglesea

3) Wandering along Southwold beach

4) Being the goalie in a Beat the Goalie competition

5) Photobombing Alastair Stewart at your local secondary school’s Head Quiz

6) Listening to Bach on the tube

8) Checking up on Red Kite nests in the Chilterns

9) Queuing for an ATM in Greece

10) Crashing a mountain bike down a hill (picture not for the faint hearted)

11) In the back garden “being irritated by the helicopters flying backwards and forwards overhead channelling all the oligarchs to Pilton”

12) Taking part in a mountain rescue charity day

13) Ironing

14) Helping baby turtles reach the sea

15) Working

16) Working

17) Working

18) Wild swimming (wild swimming was just known as ‘swimming’ when I was young. Kids today etc)

19) Eschewing Jurassic World for the Jurassic Coast

20) Watching your 13-year-old daughter compete in the National Karate Championships in Crawley

21) Making a secular capitalist pilgrimage to the Shard

22) Having a cream tea in the Cotswolds

23) Having a picnic with the dog

24) Puffin spotting off the coast of Northumberland

25) Hanging out with baby seagulls in Kent

26) Taking pictures of topless rowers at a Henley Regatta practice event

27) Enjoying a village duck race

28) Having a lovely walk in the Peak District

29) Getting drunk at home

30) “Working on a highly classified project, trying to develop cold fusion energy, while routinely fighting off international assassins hired by operators of shale gas exploration.” (not entirely sure this one is true, to be honest)

31) Climbing mountains in the Scottish Highlands (with some dogs)

32) Going to see the Grateful Dead

33) Going to see Noel Gallagher in Switzerland

34) Going to see Motorhead in Cornwall

35) Going to see a Johnny Cash tribute act

36) Hosting a Woodstock themed birthday party

37) Watching Glastonbury online with a tube of Pringles

38) Watching Glastonbury in a tent in your garden

39) Admiring your new hat

40) Encountering a terrifying Triffid-esque plant

cards.title: Summer / Share your best snaps with us
cards.rawTitle: Share your best snaps with us

item.title: Share your best summer shots with us
item.trailText: Whether it’s a melting ice-cream or a beach scene full of people soaking in the sun, we’d like to see your best photos of the summer
item.standFirst: Whether it’s a melting ice-cream or a beach scene full of people soaking in the sun, we’d like to see your best photos of the summer
item.body:
From families sunbathing in a back lane to a late night shot of Dungeness, photographers such as Martin Parr, David LaChapelle and Elaine Constantine have shown us their best summer shots. Now we’d like to see yours.

What does summer mean to you? Is it spending time with your family or escaping to another country for an adventure? You can share your summer photos and stories with us by clicking on the blue ‘Contribute’ buttons. Or if you’re out and about you can download the GuardianWitness app or look for our assignments in the new Guardian app.

  • GuardianWitness is the home of readers’ content on the Guardian. Contribute your video, pictures and stories, and browse news, reviews and creations submitted by others. Posts will be reviewed prior to publication on GuardianWitness, and the best pieces will feature on the Guardian site.
